content.description: Nice flake / crack to a jug top out.
content.protection: Gear up to .75 or pads. Could be a highball or short lead.
content.location: From the Firetower take the South Ridge trail to the first cluster of cleaned boulders. Go left from here down a slight gully about 100 yards to a long low wall. Number 48 in the Pawtuckaway Underground guide.

content.description: Stand start at the prow with a right hand sidepull sloper on the arete and a small left hand hold. Pull on with good feet and stand up to the undercling feature at about head height. figure out where to hold it and get a high left foot. Make a long reach and hard lockoff to an undercling at about 10 feet. Pull into it and figure out how to top out!
content.location: To the left of "Midnight in a Perfect World" on the obvious prow/ arete.

content.description: Stand start with right hand on flake and left hand on a bad sloping crimp. Set your feet and fire to the lip. This will either be a dead point for taller people or more of a dyno for people on the shorter side. Either way a super fun route!
content.protection: One big pad or two smaller ones
content.location: This route is directly next to Reach for the V.

content.description:
Unknown if this has been climbed before, looking for input. 

 Stand start with left hand on thin side-pull and right hand in crimp dish. Pull on and make a RH move to a crimp rail, match, work feet, make a barn-door deadpoint/dyno to triangle three finger jug. Cross, and work your way right and to the shelf top out.

 A sit start is likely doable.
content.location: Down the path below Mr. Big

content.description: Power into balance. Sit start with right hand on side pull and left hand on sloping rail. Pulling off the ground is the hardest part of this climb. Work you way straight up the face and top out directly over the start.
content.protection: Two or more pads to cover the rocks below you.
content.location: This route is directly next to V is for... on the small summit of the fire tower uppers.

content.description: Sit start on right side of the arete and work yourself into the arete and up. The crux is sticking the first move and keeping your feet.
content.location: On the right arete if you are looking at Tomahawk and V is for...

content.description:
Perfect height, great moves, and devious holds.  This powerful, delicate arete is a hidden gem and now one of my favorites in the park.  Sit start with a three finger jug for your left hand and a crimp for your right.  Slither up to two tiny crimps using a sidepull before powering into a gaston pinch.  With the help of another crimp and an undercling, make a hard deadpoint up to one of two crimps before snagging the flat sloping lip which feels like a jug. 

  V5 from the stand, starting by jumping to the gaston.
content.location: Five minutes up the Fire Tower Trail, where the trail takes a hard right turn, head left/downhill on a faint footpath where you can see the pond through the trees.  When on the footpath, this boulder is the leftmost rock that is visible.  The problem climbs the arete behind the tree.

content.description: Start with both hands in the seam on two bad crimps, make move to upper right rail and top out. Crux is getting off the ground. Stand start goes much easier at V0.
content.location: Directly next to Sunset arete

content.description: An interesting face climb with a delicate start and a fun finish.  Stand start with large feet and two thin sidepulls.  Use a crimp and a gaston and fight the barndoor to reach better holds.  Topout straight up, joining Slither at its end.
content.protection: Two pads and a spotter - pad the rock behind you!
content.location: Five minutes up the Fire Tower Trail, where the trail takes a hard right turn, head left/downhill on a faint footpath where you can see the pond through the trees.  When on the footpath, this boulder is the leftmost rock that is visible.  The problem climbs the face right of Slither.

content.description: Fun little lip traverse. Top out at the V shape in the rock.
content.location: This is on the small summit of the Upper Firetower Boulders. When turning right before the firetower to get to the uppers continue along the path to the small summit. When you are overlooking the park look directly behind you and you will see a path with the boulder on your right.

content.description:
Butt placement matters. 

  Start sitting with a RH crimp sidepull with a slopey thumbcatch and LH on a crimpy undercling. Figure out your feet and make a hard pull off the ground (crux) to reach the first slopey three finger crimp on the arete. Get a LH sloper and follow slopers up the arete to a precarious top out.
content.protection: 2 Pads, nice to place one so you can just hop down
content.location: In the warmup area, the arete just left of Jesus Every Time.

content.description: Scamper up on to the pedestal and make a few moves to flat jug, then make committing moves into the thin crack and topout.
content.location: From the Firetower head back and right from the main trail to find a fairly well travelled climbers path heading down the backside of South Mountain. There is a tall face with a few problems right at the start of the path. Follow the path down for a few minutes to find this problem and a bunch more in the immediate area.

content.description: Dirty and some broken feet but it is all there. Start on the left rising flake and traverse across the crack, top out straight up in line with the tree. There are some decent crimps over the lip to help you top this problem out.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter so you don't hit the tree
content.location: From the upper warm up area (The False summit Area with Tomahawk) turn so you are looking out over the cliff and walk right down a small path. You will start to wrap around the front of the cliff and the problem is there on your left.

content.description: Start on a bad right hand and a good left sidepull. Thuggy first move then follow ok edges to the top. Hardest move on this is the first one to the good edge.
content.location: Next to the rising crack traverse behind the upper warm up area with Tomahawk.

content.description: Jug, jug, arete, jug.  A nice, easy problem to stretch your muscles on.  Stand start with a jug in the crack on the left.  Move up right to another crack/jug, then make a fun move out right to the arete.  Topout with the help of another large hold.
content.location: Five minutes up the Fire Tower Trail, where the trail takes a hard right turn, head left/downhill on a faint footpath where you can see the pond through the trees. The footpath leads into the warmup alcove, formed by two boulder walls and a freestanding boulder.  This problem is on the back wall of the alcove.

content.description: From the obvious horizontal at head height, move up to bad slopers and make a big reach to a very slopey mono solution pocket. Get your feet up high and either bump to the slopey ball or make a hard lock off and cross to the ball. Once you've matched the ball, it's an easy move to the top. This problem is really unique for Pawtuckaway and looks much easier than it is. It's very friction dependent; long arms and good footwork will help too.
content.location:
Follow the main trail up. When it breaks right, continue heading up and slightly left on a faint (maybe nonexistent) trail. Eventually on your left you'll see a 20-foot mossy wall with an obvious crack. Skirt the wall and you'll come out in a clearing. Mr. Big is on your left. Start in the slopey horizontal at the 7-ft level and go up.  

  Note: there are several other good problems in this area worth exploring.

content.description: This is a very hard dynamic slab problem. Start by stemming in the scoop to reach left hand up to a small thumb-undercling. Match the thumb-undercling and reach out left to a terrible ripple of a crimp. Get your right foot very high on an insecure, glassy edge and generate enough momentum to launch you high and right to a good crimp on the edge of the scoop. You'll probably lose all other points of contact with the wall when you hit the crimp. Control it, match, then follow good flakes up and over the top. The finish is a little high but very easy compared to the rest. A very good problem for those that can appreciate a hard slab climb.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spot. The landing seems flat, but it's easy to roll your ankle here anyway.
content.location: Follow the main trail up; when the main trail turns right, stay on it.  100 - 200 yards from the turn, start looking into the woods on the left for a tall, just-under-vertical scoop-like wall just up and off the trail behind some pines (it's a little hard to see). That's the one.

content.description: An obvious right to left traverse with an interesting mantle to finish.  A great way to warm up or get pumped out.  Sit start beneath the tiny roof at the right end of the wall and start climbing across jugs and slopers all the way to the left arete.  Now, move straight up to two good holds and press until you're able to topout.  Although fun, the crack has a tendency to get dirty, so brush it off before you take a lap.
content.location: Five minutes up the Fire Tower Trail, where the trail takes a hard right turn, head left/downhill on a faint footpath where you can see the pond through the trees. The footpath leads into the warmup alcove, formed by two boulder walls and a freestanding boulder.  This problem traverses the obvious crack on the first wall.

content.description: A very nice finger crack. Stand start on a good hold in the base of the crack and climb straight up on great locks and laybacks. Top out in the pine needles. Good problem with a flat landing right off the trail, should see more action.
content.location: Walk past Mr. Big for about 50 feet and turn right onto the obvious trail. In 50 yards a rounded boulder with a few attractive finger cracks will be on your left. Climb the left most one. On the same boulder as Didgabringabeeralong and #73 in Bryce's guidebook.

content.description: Climb the tall dirty arete. There is a harder sit start on the left wall of the arete. The moves are fun and it's pretty tall but flakey rock and lichen detract from the quality.
content.location: From the Fire tower head back and right from the main trail up to find a fairly well travelled path down the backside of South Mountain. Follow the path for a few minutes to this problem and others in the immediate area.

content.description: A fun, short, dynamic problem that revolves around two holds.  Pull onto the wall with a good diagonal pinch/jug.  Fire straight up to a flat hidden edge on the lip and topout with a few slopers.
content.location: Five minutes up the Fire Tower Trail, where the trail takes a hard right turn, head left/downhill on a faint footpath where you can see the pond through the trees. The footpath leads into the warmup alcove, formed by two boulder walls and a freestanding boulder.  This problem is on the first wall that is split with the long horizontal crack.

content.description:
Big power moves on good holds makes this problem a lot of fun.  Sit start beneath the bulging boulder with a good edge, power up to the next juggy edge, then set up to dyno or use trickery to snag the slopey lip.  Top out. 

  The first move can feel huge, which is how the problem got it's name.  Every time someone sat down to climb, they uttered "Jesus."
content.location: Five minutes up the Fire Tower Trail, where the trail takes a hard right turn, head left/downhill on a faint footpath where you can see the pond through the trees.  When on the footpath, this boulder is the leftmost rock that is visible.  The problem climbs the face around the corner.

content.description: A nice climb up a clean, slightly overhanging wall. Good landing. Sit start in the middle of the boulder and traverse up and right along a thin crack with some finger sized pods. Make a tricky, sloping top out at the end of the crack at a respectable distance off the deck.
content.location: Follow the climber's path up and right from Midnight in a Perfect World about 50 yards. For reference, this problem is marked as #41 in the Pawtuckaway Underground guidebook, which has really good maps for this area.

content.description: Up the after on flakes and crimps.
content.location: In the obvious alcove below the Firetower.

content.description:
This is a fun climb with good movement and high rock quality that is unfortunately marred by the proximity of a large wedged block that hangs over the right side of the climb.  

  Start sitting with the left hand on a good angled edge at around 4 feet and the right hand on a low sidepull. Pull off the ground and bump the right hand to a good hold on the arete. From here, make a long move to the lip above without hitting your head on the large block (crux). Finish off with a tricky mantel, doing your best to not dab on the block.  

  This problem is #62 in the underground guidebook.
content.protection: One big pad should do. Perhaps a spotter. Maybe a helmet as well.
content.location: Located at the South Ridge boulders, which is a subset of The Fire Tower boulders. This climb is located maybe 60 yards down the hill from 'Mr. Big', in a little alcove of sorts, to the right of the large highball face that is right off the trail.

content.description:
Stand Start in the crack on just, move up on good holds to sloper for the top out. 

  Although it is not much to look at we found it pretty fun.
content.location: Five minutes up the Fire Tower Trail, where the trail takes a hard right turn, head left/downhill on a faint footpath where you can see the pond through the trees. The footpath leads into the warmup alcove, formed by two boulder walls and a freestanding boulder. This problem is the left most problem on the first wall that is split with the long horizontal crack. (The is a copy of Bryce's location description)

content.description: Highball face listed in the Underground Guidebook as a project. Line follows an obvious dike trending left to right up the center of the boulder. Stand start with opposing sidepulls in the center of the face. Crux is about halfway up. If someone else has climbed this in the past please let me know. Really fun climb and totally worth doing.
content.protection: Pads and spotters. Tall, but easy up top
content.location: Lower fire tower area to the left of Proper Pooper Placement

content.description: Enjoyable face climb right up top near the fire tower. Stand start by the hueco and head straight up on crimps. Good top out. Perhaps someone has more and better info on this route. Fill me in. Perhaps a sit had been done?
content.location: In a small alcove at the top of South Mountain. Before reaching the fire tower the alcove is off to your right directly trailside. Hemlock Arete is it’s neighbor.

content.description: An incredible line that follows a laser-cut arete using pinches and crimps. Start with left hand on a seam, right hand low on the arete and right foot on a foot chip down low. Make hard moves on slopey pinches until you can crimp your way to the top. I have not done this route, but I worked it and look forward to sending it someday. I figured it deserved a spot on MP because it is the definition of cool. Thanks to Brett Meyers for cleaning and finding this gem.
content.location: At the top of the fire tower mountain. Follow the trail all the way to the top. Just before you get to the fire tower, there will be a small dihedral/overhang on your right. This block is right off the path. The boulder problem is on the opposite side of this block.

content.description: Offwidth start to a squeeze chimney. At the top exit to the arete at a chockstone or tunnel under and pop out at the top.
content.protection: Up to .75 Camelot for a smaller crack on the chimney wall.
content.location: Take the South Ridge trail from the Firetower and follow a trail downhill to the right at the first cluster of cleaned boulders. Keep going for a few minutes along this cliff band passing a few short trad climbs / highball boulders. Number 88 in the Pawtuckaway Underground guide.

content.description: A very nice little problem with great movement. Start on a cool hueco jug at chest height. Stand up to a sloper rail that will feel like a jug if you grab it right. Use some good albeit dirty crimps to top out.
content.location: In the South Ridge Boulders downhill from the Fire Tower itself. The problem starts on the obvious hueco 8 feet left of Mr. Big.

content.description: A long crack traverse leads into a vertical crack to topout.  Sit start at the left end of the wall.  Follow the rising diagonal crack right until you reach the arete before the corner.  Climb straight up to finish.
content.location: When heading downhill on the South Ridge trail, this is the last wall on the left, split by a horizontal crack and numerous vertical cracks.  Walkoff back and to the left.

content.description: A very aesthetic crack climb. Stand start laybacking the crack and scrunch your feet up. Get a good ring lock and stand up to better holds above. Top out same as "Buddha's Belly".
content.location: 3 feet right of "Buddha's Belly", can't miss this splitter crack.

content.description:
A short problem with great, friendly holds.  My only complaint is that it isn't longer.  Start squatting with the U-shaped jug in the middle of the face and pull up and left to the edges on the bulge above the crack.  Get your foot up and move out right to a large sidepull before topping out on easy, slopey terrain. 

  Variation - Rather than move right to the sidepull, topout straight up with a sloper above the bulge.
content.location: Five minutes up the Fire Tower Trail, where the trail takes a hard right turn, head left/downhill on a faint footpath where you can see the pond through the trees. The footpath leads into the warmup alcove, formed by two boulder walls and a freestanding boulder.  This problem is on the first wall that is split with the long horizontal crack.

content.description:
A quick little problem put up at the end of the day.  Sit start with a decent left hand and right hand on the massive sloper wherever you stick.  Using a good right foot, power up and left to a loose jug, then climb easier moves to a ledge.  Drop off. 

  The jug might snap at some point making the problem harder, but the sloper is cool.
content.location: In the first outcropping of boulders on the trail, head left/downhill to the last of the boulders.  This problem is on the face that stares at the pond down below.

content.description: A very nice bulging undercling crack. Crouch start on good undercling slots and climb up and right as the crack turns into a layback flake. Continue all the way to a fun dihedral top out. Very high quality.
content.location: If looking at Masterlock, turn around and walk another 50 yards to a small gully which you can scramble up. Pass by a cool warmup wall and you should see this beautiful bulging undercling crack.

content.description: Sit start under the small roof in the crack, move to good holds over the lip and top out. Pretty fun for only climbing 2 feet isn't it?
content.location: Five minutes up the Fire Tower Trail, where the trail takes a hard right turn, head left/downhill on a faint footpath where you can see the pond through the trees. The footpath leads into the warmup alcove, formed by two boulder walls and a freestanding boulder. This problem is the right most problem on the first wall that is split with the long horizontal crack. (This is a copy of Bryce's well worded description)

content.description: Splitter crack in a corner. Crux is the topout.
content.location: From the Firetower take the South Ridge trail to the first cluster of cleaned boulders. From here go left and downhill in a slight gully for 100 yards passing a long 20-25 ft wall. There are a bunch of other problems in this little area.

content.description: Lots of boulders and boulderable outcroppings, very few climbers. The area is popular with hikers, and you're more likely to see them on the many established trails in the area. The rock tends towards the slabby side, so if you're looking for steep boulders head somewhere else. While there aren't a lot of developed problems there is potential for more to be added, and the area has two difficult, high-quality slab boulder problems worth making the trip for.
